Before having the problem of topic names with more than two elements, we have the even more pressing issue here that tenant IDs may contain characters that are not allowed and prevent the topic to be created in the first place.
URI-encoding does not work because the % character is not allowed in topic names. To solve this we could invent our own encoding logic. I am hesitating to do this because backend applications would be required to do this as well, which might be error-prone.
A second option is to restrict tenant names (I would suggest to the characters used in UUIDs). Even if we don't want to change the pattern that validates tenant IDs with a minor version of Hono, it could be documented that using Kafka requires migrating tenant IDs to this restricted character set (plus starting, to create only safe tenant IDs in our device registry code).
A third option would be to not use the tenant ID in the topic name, but a new, safe identifier. This could be stored in the tenant configuration. The drawback is that backend applications could no longer derive it from the tenant ID but need somehow to get the topic name.

I think it would be good if we could come to a final decision regarding the structure of topic names soon. FMPOV, we can't complete the API specification or implementation before that.
My proposal would be the following:

we start with using topic names with a static prefix and a dynamic second element. Then we do not need a reserved delimiter.
we separate the two elements (and possible sub-elements within the prefix) with a defined separator, which is only for human readability and not used as a technical delimiter for parsing the name.
we take the '.' as the separator. Although we then have '.' and '_' in topic names, which in principle could lead to name conflicts in Kafka metrics, no conflicts will occur with our structure of the names.
if we realize at a later time that this naming scheme is no longer sufficient for us, we can still define a technical delimiter. For the TenantIds, '.' is a good choice for the reasons mentioned above, so that we don't have to change the character again. For other dynamic elements, we can't tell which characters they contain without knowing them anyway.
the static prefixes are additionally namespaced with hono.

The result will look like this:
hono.${endpoint}.${tenant_id}. Or, more concrete: hono.event.${tenant_id}, hono.telemetry.${tenant_id}, hono.command.${tenant_id}, hono.command_response.${tenant_id}.
WDYT?
